ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Parallel plate lens with metal hole array for terahertz wave band

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Optical devices for terahertz wave band from 0.1 to 10 THz are rapidly expanding and require better designs. This paper proposes and designs a parallel plate lens with metal hole array for the terahertz wave band. The fast wave effect is due to the parallel plate. For this lens, the parallel plate spacing and hole array dimensions control the phase velocity and the focusing effect. It is not necessary to control the phase through the lens shape, which is flat, itself. The periodic analysis model extracted from the full model confirms the phase control by the metal hole array dimensions. The periodic model can be used for efficient iterative design. The full wave analysis results are also obtained by ANSYS HFSS and the focusing effect is confirmed. Phase control using both the parallel plate and the hole array enhances the focusing effect over the focusing effect controlled only by the metal hole array dimensions.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
Optical lenses for the terahertz wave band require better and more flexible designs. The material properties usually determine the lens characteristics, but is difficult to arbitrarily realize the desired refractive index using naturally occurring materials. Lenses for the terahertz wave band are commonly fabricated from high-density polymers, Tsurupica, and silicon lenses with refractive indices of 1.52, 1.56, and 3.41, respectively. For microwave frequency bands, lenses composed of electromagnetic metamaterials, sphere arrays, disk arrays, square plate arrays, and strip arrays have been proposed in [1–5]. Concave lens that use parallel plates also have been produced [1, 6]. The effective index of this structure is estimated as 0
$$<n<$$
< n <
1.

In the terahertz wave band, [7–10] present a metamaterial absorber, [11] presents an antireflection coating, [12] presents a metamaterial with an unnaturally high refractive index, and [13] and [14] present a three-dimensional metamaterial. The work in [15] proposes an artificial dielectric lens with metallic corrugated structures and that in [16] analyzes and designs artificial dielectric lens with metallic rectangular chips for the terahertz band.

This paper proposes a parallel plate lens with a metal hole array as shown in Fig. 1 and studies the focusing effect in the terahertz wave band. The phase of a TE mode in a parallel plate is fast compared with that of a TEM mode in free space. The concave lens [1, 6] produces the focusing effect due to the parallel plate spacing and lens shape. The parallel plate lens with metal hole array can control the phase velocity and produce the focusing effect through the parallel plate spacing and the hole array dimensions. Thus, the parallel plate lens with metal hole array can be a flat lens.
Fig. 1
Parallel plate lens with metal hole array

A periodic analysis model extracted from the full model confirms the phase control. Commercial EM simulators, e.g., ANSYS HFSS, are now quite powerful, but are still too computationally expensive for optimization using the full model. Hence, a lens with a large, but finite and complicated unit cell is generally cumbersome and challenging to design. The periodic model analysis [17] is fast and can easily confirm the phase variations. The periodic model is also very convenient for the iterative design procedure. The dimensions of full model are taken to be smaller than those of actual lens to reduce the time-consuming analysis. However, full wave analysis by ANSYS HFSS confirms the focusing effect in the parallel plate lens with metal hole array. Section 2 explains the lens structure details and parameters, and Sect. 3 presents the phase control by using the periodic analysis model. Finally, Sect. 4 shows the full model analysis results.

Section1.Heading: Structure and dimensions of parallel plate lens with metal hole array
Section1.Para:
Figure 1a shows the parallel plate lens with metal hole array. The plates with hole array are laminated and the holes are in the order of microns. For a fixed
$$y$$
y
value, the hole radii increase in size along the
$$x$$
x
direction to a maximum value and then decrease again as shown in Fig. 1b. For all plates, the hole radii are constant along the propagation
$$z$$
z
direction for a fixed
$$x$$
x
. The separation of the parallel plates becomes wider toward the center of the lens as shown in Fig. 1c. The excitation is a TEM mode with the electric field parallel to the metallic plate such that the TE
$$_{1}$$
1
mode is the dominant mode. The phase can be controlled by the plate spacing as well as hole dimensions.

Table 1 lists the lens parameters for the reference model and hole array patterns A, B, and C. The hole dimensions for each model are listed in Tables 2, 3, and 4. The design frequency is 0.5 THz. The full model size, which confirms the focusing effect, is small compared to the actual lens dimensions to reduce the computational load. For the reference model and for patterns A and B, the parallel plate spacings are fixed and only the hole dimensions control the phase velocity. The parallel plate spacing is 310
$$\upmu $$
μ
m for the reference model and for pattern A, and the spacing is 350
$$\upmu $$
μ
m for pattern B. The hole array dimensions for the reference model and for patterns B and C are given in Table 2, and those for pattern A are given in Table 3. In pattern C, the parallel plate spacings are varied as well to accelerate the focusing effect. The parallel plate spacings for Pattern C are listed in Table 4.

Section1.Heading: Control of fast wave effect by metal hole array
Section1.Para:
Figure 2 shows the analysis model with periodic boundary walls extracted from the full model. The periodic analysis model easily computes the phase. ANSYS HFSS is used to calculate the phase in the parallel plate lens with metal hole array, and the phase results versus hole radius are plotted in Fig. 3. The parameters in the periodic model are given in Table 1. The phase is delayed with larger hole radius, and this phase delay is used to produce the desired focusing effect.
Fig. 2
Analysis model with periodic boundary walls
Fig. 3
Phase control by metal hole radius

Section1.Heading: Lens full model analysis
Section1.Para:
Through image theory, only one-quarter of the full model is analyzed [18]. The full wave analysis results are obtained by ANSYS HFSS, where the incident electric field is 1 V/m. Figure 4 shows the full model analysis result for the reference model. The local maximum value of the electric field magnitude is 3.7 times that of the incident wave at 0.55 mm (0.92
$$\lambda _{0})$$
λ 0
)
. Figure 5 shows the magnitude of electric field in the cross section at the focusing point. The positions of half magnitude are 0.49 mm (0.82
$$\lambda _{0})$$
λ 0
)
in the xz-plane and 0.22 mm (0.37
$$\lambda _{0})$$
λ 0
)
in the yz-plane. The electric field distribution in the yz-plane falls off more rapidly than that in the xz-plane. The focusing effect in the xz-plane depends on the hole array dimensions and that in the yz-plane depends on the parallel plate spacing.
Fig. 4
Full wave analysis result for the reference model
Fig. 5
Electric field distribution in the cross section at the focusing point for the reference model

Section2.Heading: Pattern A
Section2.Para:
Figure 6 shows the full wave analysis result for pattern A. The local maximum value of the electric field magnitude is 4.0 times that of the incident wave at 0.86 mm (1.4
$$\lambda _{0})$$
λ 0
)
. Figure 7 shows the electric field in the yz-plane for pattern A and for the reference model. The focusing points are seen to be controlled by the hole array dimensions. Figure 8 shows the magnitude of electric field in the cross section at the focusing point. The positions of half magnitude are 0.46 mm (0.77
$$\lambda _{0})$$
λ 0
)
for the xz-plane and 0.26 mm (0.42
$$\lambda _{0})$$

)
for the yz-plane. The electric field distribution in the yz-plane falls off more rapidly than that in the xz-plane.

Section2.Heading: Pattern B
Section2.Para:
Figure 9 shows the full wave analysis result for pattern B. The local maximum value of the electric field magnitude is 3.7 times that of the incident wave at 1.54 mm (2.6
$$\lambda _{0})$$
λ 0
)
. Figure 10 shows the electric field in the yz-plane for pattern B and for the reference model. The focusing points are seen to be controlled by the hole array dimensions. Figure 11 shows the magnitude of electric field in the cross section at the focusing point. The positions of half magnitude are 0.38 mm (0.63
$$\lambda _{0})$$
λ 0
)
in the xz-plane and 0.47 mm (0.78
$$\lambda _{0})$$
λ 0
)
in the yz-plane. The electric field distribution in the xz-plane falls all more rapidly than the field in the yz-plane. The electric field distribution in the yz-plane is wider than that for pattern A in the yz-plane since the focusing effect is reduced due to the wider parallel plate spacing in pattern B.
Fig. 9
Full wave analysis result for pattern B
Fig. 10

Fig. 11

Section2.Heading: Pattern C
Section2.Para:
Figure 12 shows the full wave analysis result for pattern C. The local maximum value of the electric field magnitude is 6.2 times that of the incident wave at 1.02 mm (1.7
$$\lambda _{0})$$
λ 0
)
. The focusing effect is more pronounced than that of the reference model, pattern A and pattern B, since both the parallel plate spacing and hole array dimensions are adjusted. Figure 13 shows the electric field in the yz-plane for pattern C and for the reference model. It is seen that the focusing points can be controlled by the hole array dimensions and the parallel plate spacing. Figure 14 shows the magnitude of electric field in the cross section at the focusing point. The positions of half magnitude are 0.40 mm (0.67
$$\lambda _{0})$$
λ 0
)
in the xz-plane and 0.21 mm (0.35
$$\lambda _{0})$$
λ 0
)
in the yz-plane. The electric field distribution in the yz-plane falls off more rapidly than that in the xz-plane.
Fig. 12
Full wave analysis result for pattern C
Fig. 13
Electric field in the yz-plane for reference model and pattern C
Fig. 14
Electric field distribution in the cross section at the focusing point for pattern C

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: This papers propose a parallel plate lens with metal hole array. The phase velocity is controlled by the parallel plate spacing and the hole array dimensions. The lens structure is flat. The periodic model analysis confirms the phase control by the hole array dimensions. The periodic model is used for efficient iterative design. The full model analysis also confirms the focusing effect. Phase control by both the parallel plate and the hole array can enhance the focusing effect. We are planning to fabricate the lenses and measure the focusing effect.
